subject: Abi: “IKÜM taotlus seoses isikuandmete töötlemisega / GDPR Request Regarding Processing of Personal Data“ — uus kommentaar
bodyHtml:
Re: IKÜM taotlus seoses isikuandmete töötlemisega / GDPR Request Regarding Processing of Personal Data
Joel Limberg kommenteeris:

Tere!

Oleme su samasisulisele päringule vastanud juba mai alguses.

Taotluse lahendus: "veebiteenuse jpg.ope.ee" sisselogimislehel pole enam võimalik Gregor Eesmaa kasutajakonto olemasolu tuvastamine.

Suuremas plaanis on päringu sisu/etteheited oma sisulise poole pealt üsna arusaamatud. Info selle kohta, et "Gregor Eesmaa" nimeline inimene on mingil viisil seotud Jaan Poska Gümnaasiumiga, ripub avalikult internetis, sh kooli kodulehel:

https://f.stuudium.net/s/202506/110737GCvU0zBi1ojOvFkuaCKFZhDBwo/2025-06-11-at-10.34.28.jpg

Samuti juhtisime su tähelepanu sellele, et ka Tartu Ülikooli sisselogimisleht võimaldab nime alusel tuvastada ülikooliga seotud konto olemasolu või mitte-olemasolu:

https://f.stuudium.net/s/202504/280828ODqN3PssFKfPepiAPMk8CMWvq9/2025-04-28-at-11.25.44.gif

Staatuse muudatus: uus → korras

Vaata kogu teemat ja vasta: https://jpg.ope.ee/abi/i42904#c146273

llmAnalysis.thinking:
**Email Analysis and JSON Construction**

My task is to analyze this email response to a GDPR request and distill the key information into a structured JSON object.

First, I identified the language as Estonian, so my primary focus will be translation and understanding the context. The email concerns a "GDPR Request Regarding Processing of Personal Data," specifically addressing a previous query from "Joel Limberg."

I broke the email down: "Joel Limberg commented," "Hello," a response indicating the original query was answered in early May. The email then directly addresses the request's solution: the user account of "Gregor Eesmaa" can no longer be detected on the login page of the web service. They also mention that the content of the request is, in their view, unclear. They point out that information about Gregor Eesmaa is already publicly available online (linking to the school's website) and highlight that the University of Tartu has a similar login system. They state the status has been changed to "in order/fixed" and provide a link to the full topic on their system.

Now, my analysis: The email uses Estonian (`et`) and the tone leans towards informal due to the dismissive language ("quite incomprehensible") and lack of legal references.

Regarding the GDPR request, I've determined it partially addresses it; they've restricted the user account but don't provide a legal basis for processing. The email mentions personal data belonging to "Joel Limberg" and "Gregor Eesmaa." No extension was requested or granted. They *partially* acknowledge the request, indicating they fixed the issue, but disagree with the premise of the initial request, justifying their position with arguments.

The email's justification is centered around denying any substantial risk, arguing the information is public and that others follow similar practices. The remediation status is "completed" as the issue is resolved and the remediation scope is partial as it is specific to "Gregor Eesmaa's user account" and doesn't encompass a system-wide fix. There's no future remediation date because the work is done.

I believe I have a thorough understanding to create the JSON object.
